brands.description: Twitter is an online social networking service that enables users to send and read short 140-character messages called "tweets". Registered users can read and post tweets, but those who are unregistered can only read them. Users access Twitter through the website interface, SMS or mobile device app. Twitter Inc. is based in San Francisco and has more than 25 offices around the world.
brands.name: Twitter

brands.description: Netflix is a global provider of streaming movies and TV series. As of 2016, it has over 75 million subscribers. Netflix started as an American DVD-by-mail service in 1998, and began streaming in 2007. Netflix expanded with streaming to Canada in 2010 and now serves over 190 countries.
brands.name: Netflix

brands.description: GitHub is a web-based Git repository hosting service. It offers all of the distributed revision control and source code management (SCM) functionality of Git as well as adding its own features. Unlike Git, which is strictly a command-line tool, GitHub provides a Web-based graphical interface and desktop as well as mobile integration.
brands.name: GitHub

brands.description: Dyn DNS Company is an Internet performance management company, offering products to monitor, control, and optimize online infrastructure, and also domain registration services and email products.
brands.name: Dyn (company)

brands.description: Google is an American multinational technology company specializing in Internet-related services and products. These include online advertising technologies, search, cloud computing, and software. Most of its profits are derived from AdWords, an online advertising service that places advertising near the list of search results.
brands.name: Google

brands.description: Kali Linux is a Debian-derived Linux distribution designed for digital forensics and penetration testing. It is maintained and funded by Offensive Security Ltd. Mati Aharoni, Devon Kearns and RaphaÃ«l Hertzog are the core developers.
brands.name: Kali Linux

transcript.text: Now we'll be looking at one of the most significant cyber attacks in recent history, the Mirai botnet attack.
So what made this attack unique was how it leveraged Internet of Things devices to launch a massive Distributed Denial of Service, or DDoS, attack.
It exposed just how vulnerable many connected devices are and highlighted the need for a stronger IoT security.
So how does Mirai works?
Mirai starts by scanning the Internet for IoT devices, devices that are often connected directly to the Internet without proper security.
It specifically looks for those that use default or Whitlock in credentials.
Once it finds one, it tries to brute force its way in using a hard coded list of username and password paths.
After successfully logging in, Mirai downloads malware onto the device, hides itself, and disables certain system services to block recovery or other malware.
The device is now part of the botnet.
It then connects to a command and control C2 server, waiting for instructions like launching attacks or scanning for more vulnerable devices.
When instructed, all infected devices carry out a coordinated DDoS attack.
Mirai uses multiple attack types, from SYN and egg floods that explode the exploit, the TCP handshake to UDP floods and HTTP request floods, which overwhelm servers with fake traffic.
Now I'll be moving on to the timeline of the incident.
So the first signs of Mirai were detected in August 2016, when a researcher flagged it as a malware targeting IoT.
By September, it was actively launching attacks on Minecraft servers and small businesses, rapidly growing its network of infected devices.
Things escalated when on September 30th, the Mirai source code was released publicly on the hacker forum.
This allowed anyone to create their own versions of the botnet, which led to a spike in similar attacks globally.
Then came the infamous DNS attack.
On October 21st, Mirai targeted Din, a major DNS provider with an unprecedented 1.2 terabytes per second of traffic.
Major sites like Twitter, Netflix, GitHub, and Spotify were all taken offline.
In late 2016, FBI and cybersecurity firms began investigating.
Companies also started rolling out firmware updates and improving DDoS protection.
Cloudflare, Amazon, and Google all stepped up their security services.
Eventually, in December 2017, the creators of Mirai were identified and arrested.
They were sentenced to community service and probation, likely in exchange for cooperation and support in cybersecurity investigations.
But the damage didn't end there.
Since the source code was public, it led to many new variants, like the Mosi botnet in 2020.
Even now, IoT security remains a global issue, with millions of devices still exposed.
Next, we'll demonstrate a seen flood attack between two virtual machines showcasing its.

cyberattacks in history, leveraging Internet of Things (loT)
devices to launch massive Distributed Denial-of-Service
Â· Mirai scans the internet for loT devices (e.g. IP cameras, routers)
Â· Use default or weak login credentials (e.g. admin/admin)
Â· Once a vulnerable device is found, Mirai uses a hardcoded list of default
Â· If a match is found, Mirai logs in via Telnet or SSH, gaining access to the device
Â· After Mirai gains access to the device, it downloads the Mirai malware onto the
Â· Malware hides itself and disables system services to block or kill other competing
malware, and block further access to prevent users from recovering their devices
Â· Device becomes part of the botnet
. The infected bot connects to a C2 server and waits for instructions or commands
Â· Launch a DDoS attack on a specific IP
Â· Once commanded, all the infected devices will simultaneously execute a massive
DDoS attack using various methods as follows
Overwhelm the target server with incomplete TCP handshake requests
Overloading the target with excessive acknowledgement packets
Flooding the network with massive amounts of random UDP packets
Sends fake HTTP requests to exhaust web servers and resources
Security Researcher MalwareMustDie identifies Mirai as a new malware
targeting loT devices. It spreads by scanning the internet for devices with
Mirai launches DDoS attacks on Mlnecraft servers and small businesses. The
botnet grows rapidly, infecting thousands of loT devices.
Mirai's creator published the source code on a hacker forum which allowed
cybercriminals to create modified versions of Mirai, leading to a surge in new
Dyn DNS attack happened, which caused the greatest impact. Attack size
was of 1.2 Tbps. Websites affected include Twitter, Netflix, Github, Spotify
Security response began in late 2016 when FBI and cybersecurity experts
investigate Mirai and its impact. Companies release firmware updates to
secure loT devices. DDoS protection services from companies such as
Cloudflare, Google, Amazon expanded their security measures.
Arrest of Mirai creators and given community service and probation.
